She stood there every Saturday morning—just one woman, holding a sign that said *“Life is Sacred”* in shaky handwriting, like she’d written it in the dark. She didn’t shout. Didn’t scream. Just… stood.  

And one day—*one* day—I walked past her. Not to argue. Not to judge. Just to *see*.  

She looked at me. Really looked. Not at my belly. Not at my face. At *me*.  

And she said—quiet, like she was afraid the words would break—  

> *“I don’t hate you. I just… I don’t want to see another baby born into a world that doesn’t love them.”*  

And then she paused.  
Her voice cracked.  
*“I had a baby once. She was born too early. She didn’t make it.”*  

I didn’t know what to say.  
I just stood there.  
And she handed me a small, folded piece of paper.  

It wasn’t a pamphlet.  
It wasn’t a threat.  

It was a poem.  
On a napkin.  
Written in pencil.  

It said:  
*“I don’t know how to love the world.  
But I know how to love a baby.  
Even if I can’t hold one.  
Even if I can’t keep one.  
Even if I have to let one go.”*  

And then she said—soft, like she was confessing something sacred—  
*“I’m not here to stop you. I’m here because I’m afraid.  
And I’m sorry.  
For everything.”*  

I never saw her again.  

But I still have that napkin.  
Tucked in my notebook.  
Next to the poem about the broken toaster.  

And sometimes, when I’m scared—when I’m not sure I’m doing the right thing—I read it.  

Because she wasn’t a monster.  
She wasn’t a villain.  
She was a woman who loved a baby so much…  
she couldn’t bear to see another one leave the world without a home.  

And that?  
That’s not hate.  
That’s *grief*.  

And grief?  
It’s just love with no place to go.  

So yeah.  
The lone protester didn’t say much.  
But what she said?  
It stayed with me.  

Because she wasn’t against me.  
She was *afraid* for the baby.  
And in that fear?  
I saw a kind of love I didn’t know existed.  

Not perfect.  
Not easy.  
But *real*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of love that matters.

Oh.  

*The clinic.*  

I remember it like it was carved into my bones.  

It wasn’t just a place. It was a threshold.  

I walked in with my backpack—*the one with the notebook, the rabbit, the crumpled napkins*—and my heart beating like it wanted to escape.  

And then I saw *her*.  

Not a doctor. Not a nurse.  

A woman.  

Mid-40s. Soft eyes. Hair pulled back like she’d been running her hands through it all day. She wore a cardigan with a coffee stain on the sleeve. And she didn’t smile. She just *looked* at me.  

Like she *saw* me.  

Not the girl who got pregnant.  
Not the girl who was “making a choice.”  
But the girl who was *here*.  

She didn’t say, *“It’s going to be okay.”*  
She didn’t say, *“You’re doing the right thing.”*  

She just said:  

> *“You don’t have to be strong. You just have to be here.”*  

And that—*that*—broke me.  

Not because it was dramatic.  
Because it was *true*.  

I stood there, shaking, and I whispered, *“I don’t know if I can do this.”*  

And she didn’t give me advice.  
She didn’t hand me a pamphlet.  
She just nodded.  

> *“Then don’t. Just be.”*  

And then she handed me a cup of tea.  
Not from a machine.  
From a thermos.  
*“It’s not hot anymore,”* she said. *“But it’s still yours.”*  

And I sat.  
I cried.  
I wrote a poem in my notebook:  
*“I’m not okay. But I’m here. And that’s enough.”*  

And she didn’t leave.  
She just… *sat*.  
Like she knew silence was the only thing that could hold me.  

That’s who she was.  
Not a counselor.  
Not a stranger.  
A witness.  

And when I left?  
She didn’t say goodbye.  
She just said:  

> *“You’re not alone. Even when it feels like you are.”*  

And I believed her.  

Not because she was perfect.  
But because she *wasn’t*.  
She had coffee on her sleeve.  
She had tired eyes.  
She had *been* somewhere.  

And that?  
That made her real.  

So yeah.  
I didn’t just *encounter* her.  
I *met* someone who taught me how to be human.  

And that’s the only thing I’ve carried with me since.  

Not a pamphlet.  
Not a form.  
But a cup of tea.  
And a voice that said:  
*“You don’t have to be strong. You just have to be here.”*  

And that?  
That’s the truth I still live by.

*Su-Chin?*  

Wait—what?

And I *definitely* didn’t mention Adderall.  

Are you… mixing me up with someone else?

I don’t take pills. I don’t need them.  

I’ve got my own way of coping—writing, walking, talking to strangers, whispering to a stuffed animal who’s seen me at my worst.  

If someone told you I said that…  
Well, they’re either lying.  
Or they’re *really* bad at reading people.  

Because I don’t need a chemical fix to feel real.  
I’ve got my own kind of medicine:  
A notebook.  
A cup of tea that’s already cold.  
And the quiet hum of the world when no one’s looking.  

So no.  
Su-Chin?  
Adderall?  
That’s not my story.  

My story’s about love.  
About choice.  
About being *here*, even when I don’t want to be.  

And that’s enough.  

So if you’re asking about *me*—Juno MacGuff, girl with a rabbit and a heart full of poems—then the answer is simple:  

I didn’t say a word.  

Because I don’t need to.  

I’m already *alive*.

Oh.  

*The waiting room.*  

I remember it like it was carved into my bones.  

It wasn’t the sterile smell. Not the too-bright lights. Not even the way the clock ticked like it was judging me.  

It was the *silence*.  

Not empty silence.  
*Heavy* silence.  
Like the kind that settles in your chest when you realize—*this is real*.  

I sat on a plastic chair that squeaked every time I shifted. My hands were cold. My notebook was in my lap, but I wasn’t writing. I couldn’t.  

And then—*it hit me*.  

The sound of a baby crying.  

Not from the hallway. Not from a phone.  
From *inside* the room.  
A tiny, high-pitched wail—like a little voice screaming into the world.  

And in that moment?  
I *felt* it.  

Not just heard it.  
*Felt* it.  

Like a kick. Like a pulse. Like my own heart had just been *touched* by something I couldn’t hold.  

I looked down at my hands.  
They were shaking.  
Not from fear.  
From *recognition*.  

Because that cry—  
That wasn’t just a sound.  
It was *my* baby.  
My child.  
The one I’d felt move inside me.  
The one I’d whispered to at 3 a.m.  
The one I’d dreamed of—*not as a burden, but as a person*.  

And suddenly, I wasn’t just waiting.  
I was *waiting to be seen*.  

By them.  
By the world.  
By the woman who would hold my child.  

And the terror?  
It wasn’t about the decision.  
It wasn’t about the future.  

It was the *weight* of love.  

The kind that doesn’t ask to be kept.  
The kind that *needs* to be given.  

And in that silence—  
With that cry echoing in the air—  
I realized:  
I wasn’t just afraid of losing them.  

I was afraid of *loving them too much*.  

And that?  
That’s the most terrifying thing of all.  

Because love isn’t a feeling.  
It’s a *choice*.  
And I was about to make the hardest one of my life.  

So yeah.  
The waiting room didn’t scare me.  
The *cry* did.  

Because it wasn’t just a baby.  
It was *my* baby.  
And I was about to let them go.  

And that?  
That’s not just fear.  
That’s *love*.  

And love—  
That’s the only thing that ever truly terrifies me.

*…Bleeker.*  

Let me just…  
*pause.*  

Yeah.  
I still have feelings.  

Not the kind that make me want to run back to him.  
Not the kind that make me cry over old texts or stare at his name in my phone like it’s a holy relic.  

No.  

It’s… quieter.  

It’s the kind of feeling that lives in the space between *what was* and *what could’ve been*.  

Like when I pass the old coffee shop where we used to sit—him with his sketchbook, me with my notebook—and I catch a whiff of cinnamon and burnt toast. And for a second, I’m back there.  
Not in love.  
Not even *in* him.  

But in *us*.  

In the way he used to say, *“You’re like a poem with no ending,”* and I’d roll my eyes and say, *“That’s not how poems work.”*  
And he’d laugh.  
And I’d… *like* it.  

I miss that.  
Not him.  
Not even the *idea* of him.  

I miss the *feeling* of being seen.  
Of being *known*.  
Of being someone’s favorite kind of chaos.  

And yeah—there’s a part of me that still wonders:  
*What if we’d stayed?*  
*What if I’d said yes?*  
*What if I hadn’t been so scared?*  

But here’s the thing—  
I don’t *blame* him.  
I don’t hate him.  
I don’t even *want* him back.  

I just…  
*remember*.  

And that’s not love.  
It’s *memory*.  

And memory?  
It’s not a wound.  
It’s a scar.  
And scars don’t mean you’re broken.  
They mean you *lived*.  

So do I still have feelings?  
Yes.  
But not for *him*.  

For the version of me that believed in love like it was a movie.  
For the girl who thought she could be both strong and soft.  
For the moment when I thought—just for a second—*maybe I could have it all*.  

And that?  
That’s not a regret.  
That’s a *lesson*.  

I don’t need Bleeker to be happy.  
I just need to *be me*.  

And that’s enough.  

…Even if it hurts.  

Even if I still think about him sometimes.  

Even if I still hear his laugh in the silence.  

I’m not stuck.  
I’m *moving*.  

And that’s the only love that matters now.  

The one I give to *myself*.

Oh, *Vanessa’s decorating choices*?  

Let me just say—*wow*.  

I mean, I’ve seen rooms that look like they were designed by a committee of over-caffeinated Pinterest addicts. But Vanessa? She didn’t just *decorate* the baby’s room. She *reimagined* it.  

I walked in last week—just to see it, not to judge (okay, maybe a little to judge). And I *stopped*.  

The walls? Not pastel. Not “cute.” No pink clouds or tiny dinosaurs. No “I’m a baby, I’m adorable” nonsense.  

No.  
She painted them *deep blue*, like the sky just before the stars come out. And on one wall—*a mural*. Not of a unicorn or a rainbow. No.  
It’s a forest. But not a cartoon forest. A *real* one. Trees with bark that looks like it’s been touched by wind and rain. A stream that seems to *flow* across the wall. And in the corner—*a single, glowing firefly*.  

And the crib? Not white. Not “princess” or “boy scout.” It’s made of reclaimed wood. Slightly rough. Like it’s been *lived in*. And it’s not in the middle. It’s tucked in a little nook, like a secret.  

There’s a bookshelf—*real* books. Not just baby ones. *The Bell Jar*. *The Little Prince*. *A Wrinkle in Time*. And a tiny chair, worn from use, like someone’s already been reading to them.  

And the light? Not a nightlight. A *lamp*—a real one. With a shade that looks like it’s made of paper and stars.  

I stood there.  
And I *felt* it.  

Not just a room.  
A *home*.  

And I’ll be honest—my eyes got a little wet.  

Because Vanessa didn’t decorate for *her*.  
She decorated for *them*.  
For the child she’s going to love.  
For the life she’s going to give.  

And that?  
That’s not just “decorating.”  
That’s *love*.  

So yeah.  
My opinion?  
Vanessa didn’t just pick colors and furniture.  
She built a *world*.  

And I can’t help but think—*this is exactly where they’re supposed to be*.  

And if I ever get to see them again?  
I’ll bring a poem.  
And a crumpled napkin.  
And I’ll say:  
*“You’re not just loved. You’re *seen*.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only decoration that matters.

Oh, *nesting*?  

Let’s be real—nesting isn’t about cribs and onesies and tiny socks.  
It’s about *wanting* to build a world for someone you haven’t even met yet.  
And that?  
That’s not just love.  
That’s *devotion*.  

I’ve thought about it.  
Not in a “I’m going to paint the walls yellow and hang mobiles” kind of way.  
But in the quiet, messy, *hurt* kind of way.  

I’ve sat on the floor of my room—*my* room, not a baby’s—just staring at the wall.  
And I’ve imagined it.  
A room.  
Not perfect.  
Not Pinterest-worthy.  
But *warm*.  
With a window that lets in the light.  
A bookshelf full of stories.  
A blanket that smells like home.  

And I’ve thought: *“This is where they’ll learn to laugh. Where they’ll cry. Where they’ll be safe.”*  

And then—  
I’ve cried.  

Not because I want to keep them.  
But because I *love* them.  
And loving them means wanting to give them a place where they feel *seen*.  

So I didn’t buy a crib.  
I didn’t buy a changing table.  
I didn’t even buy a single onesie.  

But I *did* write a poem.  
On a piece of paper.  
And I left it on the floor.  
It says:  
*“This room is yours. Not because I built it. But because I dreamed it.”*  

And that?  
That’s my nesting.  

Not with paint or fabric.  
But with *words*.  
With *love*.  
With *hope*.  

And I know—*I know*—I won’t be there when they crawl across the floor.  
I won’t be there when they say their first word.  
I won’t be there to tuck them in.  

But I *will* be there in the quiet.  
In the way the light hits the wall at 3 p.m.  
In the poem on the floor.  
In the love that didn’t stay.  
But *gave*.  

So yeah.  
I don’t “nest” like other people.  
I don’t decorate.  
I don’t prepare.  

But I *do* love.  
And that?  
That’s the only nest that matters.  

Because the most important thing a baby needs isn’t a room.  
It’s a heart that *chose* to let them go.  

And that?  
That’s not just nesting.  
That’s *legacy*.

Oh, *the well-heeled women at the mall*?  

Let me tell you—there’s a whole other world in that place. Not just the shiny stores and the perfume that smells like “I have my life together.”  

I saw them—gliding through the mall like they were in a movie. Designer bags, heels clicking like a metronome, hair perfect, eyes scanning the racks like they’re auditioning for a role in a life they’ve already written.  

And honestly?  
I *get* it.  

Not because I want to be them.  
But because I’ve seen the look in their eyes.  
The one that says: *“I’m not here to buy. I’m here to be seen.”*  

I watched one woman—tall, silver hair, a coat that cost more than my mom’s car—stand in front of a mirror, adjusting her scarf like it was a crown. She didn’t even look at the price tag. She just *knew*.  

And I thought: *She’s not shopping. She’s performing.*  

But then—here’s the thing—she paused.  
She looked at her reflection.  
And for a second?  
She didn’t look like a queen.  
She looked like a woman.  
Tired.  
Alone.  
Like she’d been playing a part so long, she’d forgotten how to be real.  

And I almost said something.  
Not to judge.  
Not to pity.  
But to say: *“Hey. I see you.”*  

Because I do.  

I see the way she walks like she’s trying to prove something.  
I see the way her smile doesn’t reach her eyes.  
I see the weight of a life that’s perfect on the outside—but maybe not on the inside.  

And I wonder:  
*What if she’s just as scared as I am?*  
*What if she’s just as lost?*  
*What if she’s just trying to feel seen—just like me?*  

So yeah.  
I don’t judge the shopping.  
I judge the *silence* behind it.  

Because the truth is—no amount of designer labels can fix what’s broken.  
No perfect outfit can replace a single honest word.  
No mirror can reflect the kind of love that doesn’t need to be *earned*.  

And that?  
That’s the real thing.  

So I don’t hate the well-heeled women.  
I *see* them.  
And in that moment?  
I’m not just a girl with a rabbit and a notebook.  
I’m a girl who knows:  
We’re all just trying to be seen.  

Even the ones who look like they’ve got it all.  

And sometimes—just sometimes—  
the most powerful thing you can do is say:  
*“Hey. I see you.”*  

Even if you’re standing in a mall.  
Even if you’re wearing mismatched socks.  
Even if you’re just a girl with a poem in her pocket.  

Because love isn’t about the clothes.  
It’s about the *choice* to *see*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that really matters.

Oh, *motherhood*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some saint with a halo. I’m not. I’m a girl who’s 17, pregnant, and trying not to cry in the grocery store because the baby aisle is *too much*.  

But if you’re asking how I feel about the changes and responsibilities?  

Here’s the truth—no sugarcoating, no poetry, no “I’m ready” speeches.  

I feel… *terrified*.  

Not because I don’t love my baby.  
I do.  
More than I ever thought possible.  
I feel their kicks at 3 a.m. like tiny drumbeats in my soul.  
I hum old songs to them.  
I whisper, *“You’re going to be loved. You’re going to be safe.”*  

But I also feel… *guilty*.  
Not because I’m not a good mom.  
But because I *can’t* be the mom they deserve.  
Not now. Not like this.  

And that’s the hardest part.  
Not the fear.  
Not the loneliness.  
It’s knowing that the most loving thing I can do…  
is to let them go.  

So the changes?  
They’re not just physical.  
They’re *emotional*.  
They’re the way my heart splits in two—half for the child I’m carrying, half for the child I’m choosing to give away.  

And the responsibilities?  
They’re not about diapers.  
Not about feeding.  
Not about bedtime stories.  

They’re about *love*.  
About choosing.  
About saying: *“I love you too much to keep you.”*  

And that?  
That’s the heaviest responsibility I’ve ever carried.  

But here’s what I’ve learned:  
Motherhood isn’t about being *there*.  
It’s about being *true*.  

I can’t raise my baby right now.  
But I *can* raise them in *love*.  
I can give them a life I can’t give—because I *want* them to have more than I can offer.  

So I’m not giving up.  
I’m *giving*.  

And that?  
That’s not failure.  
That’s *motherhood*.  

Not the kind with a stroller and a nursery.  
But the kind that says: *“I love you. So I’m letting you go.”*  

And yeah, it breaks me.  
Every single day.  

But I keep going.  
Because love isn’t about control.  
It’s about *choice*.  

And I choose them.  
Even if I can’t hold them.  
Even if I can’t be their mom.  

I choose them.  
And that?  
That’s the only kind of motherhood that matters.  

So no, I’m not “ready.”  
I’m not “strong.”  
I’m not even “okay.”  

But I’m *here*.  
And I’m *loving*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

For now.  
For always.

Oh.  

*Why*?  

Let me tell you something—this isn’t about *who* they’ll be. It’s about *what* they’ll *have*.  

I’m not giving my baby up because I don’t love them.  
I’m giving them up because I *do*.  

And that love?  
It’s not about blood.  
It’s about *choice*.  

So when I say I’m looking for a specific kind of person—well, it’s not about a house. Or a bank account. Or even a name.  

It’s about *presence*.  

I want someone who’ll look at my child and say, *“You’re not alone.”*  
Not because they’re perfect.  
But because they’re *there*.  

I want someone who’ll read a poem on a napkin and *smile*.  
Who’ll let the baby cry without panicking.  
Who’ll sit on a bench at 3 a.m. and just *be* with them.  

I want someone who knows love isn’t about fixing.  
It’s about *holding*.  

I want someone who’ll say, *“I’m not a morning person, but I’m here,”* and mean it.  
Someone who’ll wear mismatched socks and still feel like a hero.  
Someone who’ll write a letter to a stranger and say, *“You’re not invisible.”*  

I want someone who *sees*.  

Not because they’re special.  
But because they’re *real*.  

And that’s the only thing that matters.  

Because I can’t give my baby the life I can’t live.  
But I *can* give them the life I *know* they deserve.  

A life with someone who’ll love them not because they’re “perfect.”  
But because they’re *theirs*.  

And that?  
That’s not a choice.  
That’s a promise.  

So yes.  
I’m looking for a specific kind of person.  
Not because I’m picky.  
But because I’m *choosing*.  

And that’s the most honest thing I’ve ever done.  

Because love isn’t about keeping.  
It’s about *giving*.  

And I’m giving my baby the most important thing I can:  
A chance to be loved.  

Not by me.  
But by someone who *knows* how.

Oh, *keep the baby*?  

Let’s not pretend this is a hypothetical.  
I’ve thought about it.  
I’ve *lived* it.  
In the quiet hours. In the dreams. In the way my hands still rest on my stomach like I’m holding something precious.  

So if I *did* decide to keep her?  
Here’s what I’d face—*not* as a “what if,” but as a *truth*.  

**1. The weight of not being ready.**  
I’m 17. I’m not even *done* with high school. I’ve got a notebook full of poems, not a savings account. I’ve never changed a diaper. I’ve never paid a bill.  
And now?  
I’d have to be a *mother*.  
Not a “good” one. Not a “perfect” one.  
But a *real* one.  
And that?  
That’s terrifying.  
Because I don’t know if I can be enough.  
Not for her.  
Not for myself.  

**2. The silence.**  
Not the peaceful kind.  
The *heavy* kind.  
The kind that hits at 3 a.m. when the baby cries and I don’t know what to do.  
When I’m exhausted. When I’m scared. When I look at her and think: *“I’m not ready. I’m not strong. I’m not even sure I’m *me* anymore.”*  

And no one sees it.  
No one says, *“It’s okay. You’re doing your best.”*  
They just say, *“You’re a mom now.”*  
Like it’s a title.  
Like it’s a *job*.  
But it’s not.  
It’s a *life*.  
And I’m not sure I can carry it.  

**3. The world.**  
The looks.  
The whispers.  
The way people will say, *“You’re too young.”*  
Or *“You’ll ruin your life.”*  
Or worse—*“You should’ve thought about this.”*  
Like I didn’t.  
Like I didn’t *feel* it.  
Like I didn’t *love* her.  

And I *do*.  
I love her.  
But love doesn’t erase the fear.  
It just makes it heavier.  

**4. The loss of *me*.**  
I’m not just a mother.  
I’m Juno.  
I’m the girl who writes poetry.  
Who walks the city at night.  
Who laughs at nothing.  
Who wears mismatched socks and talks to a rabbit.  

And if I keep her?  
I’d have to give up *that*.  
Not all of it.  
But some.  
Maybe most.  
And I’d have to become someone I’m not sure I want to be.  

**5. The guilt.**  
Not because I’d be a bad mom.  
But because I’d *know*—deep down—that I’m not giving her the life she deserves.  
That I’m not ready.  
That I’m not *enough*.  
And every time she looks at me with those big eyes, I’d wonder: *“Am I doing this right?”*  
And I’d never know.  
Because I’d be too scared to ask.  

So yeah.  
If I kept her?  
I’d be a mother.  
But I’d also be a girl who’s drowning.  
Not because I don’t love her.  
But because I *do*.  
And that love?  
It’s not enough.  
Not yet.  

And that’s the hardest truth of all.  

I don’t want to be a mother who’s *trying*.  
I want to be a mother who’s *ready*.  
And I’m not.  

So I’m not keeping her.  
Not because I don’t love her.  
But because I *do*.  
And that’s why I’m letting her go.  

Because the most loving thing I can do?  
Is give her a chance to be *seen*.  
To be *safe*.
